body.p:
Your letter of the 5th was received the day following after the bank had
closed, or else, it is highly probable, that you would have been in possession of the enclosed
change for two or three days; but as I could not get the immense an count before
Friday morning, I had no chance of sending or writing before this morning.
When I presented the notable check to the teller, he smiled, and well he might; it
was already eight & half months old and so big at one; and then its long journey
over stork and dale, it was enough to make any one laugh. But if you
or Abbot have more such things to attend to, I shall serve you with
the greatest promptitude. Please to write or tell this to the gentleman,
whenever you write to him or see him. I have not a great deal to do and
the majority of the banks are within half a mile of my residence in
Market, Chestnut, and second Streets, and so it cannot cost me a great deal
of trouble. Besides, the number of banks is much smaller than in New_
York, and I almost think I can enumerate them easily. Let us see: the
United States Bank; Farmers & Mechanics; & the North American Banks in Ches
nut; the Schuylkill & Commercial Banks in Market; the Philadelphia
Bank, corner of 4th & Chesnut; Girard's Bank, Third near Walnut the Penn,
sylvania & Mechanics Bank in Second between Walnut & Chesnut and the Mechanics in second between Chesnut
and Market. I do not believe, that there is another bank in the City proper; but there are at least three more in the liberties; in Southwark, the Bank of Southwark; in Callowhill street the Penntownship Bank and in the
Countryside of Vine street, the Northern Liberties Bank; all these establish_
ments are in good repute, and rather more safe, than the New Yorkers. But
one Bank, I believe the Mechanics, had applied last winter for a renewal of
charter, and it was refused for the present, upon the following ridiculous pretext:
while the subscription for the relieve of Jefferson was going about, the cashier
or a director (I know not which) was applied to to contribute his mite?, which he
refused to do, with using some insulting language. This was mentioned in the house of de,
legates, and it produced a powerful effect, as the bill was immediately laid

Upon the table, and I am told, that the redoubtable German members will not vote
for a new charter to this bank, till they change the name to Jefferson Bank.
This surely is ridiculous enough, but I am also told, that this bank when first
chartered, it was in the hands of Republicans, but has since got into those
of Federalists!! and then they have indulged a little in unwarrantable spend_
ations, like perhaps, most other banks. But you may rely upon the
truth about of the story about the collecting for Jefferson, as this was in the
papers.__

You seem to give me up for a bad job; you are however mistaken, I listen
to the advice of every one, and this very thing of hearing every one perplexes
me so much, for I frequently do not know, which side to turn to. I have
had a plenty of cheap advice, but for real good assistance that is to come
yet.__ You deplore my bad luck, that Miss Etting has not been Master
Etting; but calm your regrets, for boys bring nothing, and girls bring nothing,
I was at three Beriths and two weddings, and not one cent of offerings or
presents. The Bridegrooms paid me one 20 the other 10 Dollars, and though the
families and guests on both occasions are rich, the Hazan alas! Did not count
his fingers blue by the profits....This however must be expected in Philadelphia
where cold civility pays for all things. It is well that I am not covetuous,
or else I should be greatly disappointed. But I will not complain, for I see
that I am doing so much better than many young men with ten times my
knowledge and opportunities of pushing themselves forward.__

You do not like my newspaper scribbling; you are right partly, but
the price you said was just my first offence for more than a year; yet it
was flatteringly received, and even the old critics and terror of authors,
Mr. Walsh called it interesting. But if you as little to do as I have, you
would have little doubt, be oftener caught poaching, than I have
been.__Uncle has not written to me for more than two weeks. I am glad,
